awd_titl_txt: CI-EN: SystemOnTPTP - Online Services for Automated Theorem Proving in Classical Logic
awd_abstract_narration:
Automated Theorem Proving (ATP) is concerned with the development and use of systems that automate sound reasoning: the derivation of conclusions that follow inevitably from facts. This capability lies at the heart of many important computational tasks, e.g., formal methods for software and hardware design and verification, the analysis of network security protocols, solving hard problems in mathematics, analysis of social systems, inference for the semantic web etc. Despite increased usage of ATP, the complexities of preparing problems in a logic, installing and executing appropriate ATP systems, and extracting useful information from the ATP system's output often present a barrier to using ATP. The software infrastructure, which have been available to the community for almost a decade now, overcomes these barriers by providing online services for ATP in classical logic. The NSF CRI program will help to upgrade the hardware that hosts this infrastructure. 

The system has three components:  first, it provides tools for preparing ATP problems, it then provides services that are used to solve ATP problems, and finally the service provides tools for analyzing the output and the solutions. All three components are available through interactive web interfaces for humans, and application programming interfaces. The hardware consists of a server used for building and testing ATP systems and tools before they are made available, and a compute server used to service requests from users. The hardware upgrade will make it possible for the system to continue to offer the most recent versions of ATP systems and tools, while maintaining the necessary performance and response levels.

por.por_cntn:
Automated Theorem Proving (ATP) is concerned with the development and use of systems that automate sound reasoning: the derivation of conclusions that follow inevitably from facts. The theoretical and practical strengths of ATP have enabled and motivated users, in many different application domains, to cast their problems into ATP problems. Despite increased usage of ATP, the complexities of preparing problems in a logic, installing and executing appropriate ATP systems, and extracting useful information from the ATP systems' output, often present a barrier to using ATP. In order to overcome the barriers it is necessary for the ATP community to provide comfortable means for users (both human and computer) to interface with ATP systems and tools. The infrastructure enhancement funded by this grant provided upgraded hardware for the existing SystemOnTPTP services, which provides online access to a wide range of ATP systems and tools.

The SystemOnTPTP service provides a comfortable means for users (both human and computer) to interface with ATP systems and tools. This allows them to focus on their application domain, without having to deal with the complexities of preparing problems in a logic, installing and executing appropriate ATP systems, and extracting useful information from the ATP systems' output. Users of the SystemOnTPTP service are able to make faster and better progress in their application domains. Within the STEM disciplines, a significant user of the SystemOnTPTP service is the Isabelle interactive proof development environment, whose Sledgehammer component uses the SystemOnTPTP service to automatically discharge subgoals in the theory development. Isabelle is being used in serious research and application areas, e.g., software verification, network protocol analysis, system security, etc. Users in areas of Arts & Humanties (philosophy) and Social Sciences (social choice theory, management, geography) have also used ATP in their disciplines. The SystemOnTPTP service funded by this grant will have an impact on these non-STEM application disciplines.

The project accomplished its goals: the new hardware was purchased and installed, the SystemOnTPTP software installed, and the service made available to ATP researchers and users. The new hardware provided the opportunity to upgrade all the ATP systems and tools that are supported to 64-bit (the old hardware was only 32-bit), thus providing strengthened capability. Users have been able to use the enhanced SystemOnTPTP since the summer of 2015. The availability of the upgraded SystemOnTPTP service led to the opportunity to give a tutorial on the TPTP world, including the SystemOnTPTP service, at the 11th Reasoning Web Summer School, held in Berlin, Germany in August 2015. This trained an audience of about 50 international ATP researchers and developers how to use the SystemOnTPTP service, as provided by this grant. Specific outcomes have been increased availability oif processing power in the SystemOnTPTP service, the availability of 64-bit version of the latest ATP systems and tools, and training of new SystemOnTPTP users. The overall outcome has been to provide an enhanced SystemOnTPTP service to developers and users of ATP, across of range of disciplines, applications, and user groups. In the long term, the positive impact of effective use of ATP as a formal tool in the complex reasoning that underlies much of the software that is part of modern lifestyles, will extend the lifespan of this project well beyond the funded period.
